Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution Mass Spectrometer/UPLC System
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Missouri to acquire a high resolution mass spectrometer coupled with an ultra-high performance liquid chromatography system. The instrument will be used to help further our understanding of proteins in a variety of plants including soybean, corn, and elderberry. It will also be used to examine fertility loss in animals at the protein level in support of agriculture. The University is collaborating with Evans Analytical Group (EAG) Columbia (a GLP and CGMP-compliant product development and analytical testing services company based in Columbia, MO) in a continuing industry internship program for undergraduates. Each spring undergraduate interns participate in an intensive four-week training course. This in-depth course offers a select set of high-caliber undergraduates an opportunity to develop analytical skills, with an emphasis on separations and mass spectrometry, in preparation for being employed by EAG Columbia as summer interns. Biochemistry and Chemistry undergraduate students will also use the instrument in advanced lab classes to further their understanding of modern instrumentation.

Mass spectrometry is an essential method for determining the structure of large biomolecules such as proteins. It is also possible to use this method to examine modifications to proteins. The acquisition of the high resolution mass spectrometer will allow the investigators of the project to perform quantitative protein analyses, develop new analysis capabilities, and improve instrument access at the University of Missouri. The major users of the instrument have active research programs examining protein changes in a variety of plants and animals.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award allowed for the acquisition of a chromatography system coupled to a high-resolution mass spectrometer. The instrumentation has been installed and validated. The chromatography system allows for the separation of complex peptide mixtures in a relatively short period of time. The chromatography time is reduced by a factor of two over our older system. The peptides are then identified by the mass spectrometer. Bioinformatic analysis of the data allows for the determination of the proteins present in the sample. We have developed methods to quantitatively determine the proteins present without the use of isotopic labeling reagent. This is a major step forward in protein analysis. We have examined the proteins present in cells, plants, and animal models. The results of these studies have been presented at national and international meetings. One manuscript has been publisher, another manuscript submitted and several are in preparation. A number of graduate students and post-doctoral scholars have been trained in the use of the instrument. The training program is on-going. We also partnered with Eurofins in Columbia, MO. We trained a number of undergraduate student interns in modern life science techniques. The students then spent a summer at Eurofins performing a variety of analyses.

 


Last Modified: 12/09/2019
Modified by: C. Michael Greenlief
